inlineContent.text: Each example in this repository contains a
and
. The
is
always
used to perform the final build, but the
can be used to improve the development experience.
The examples’ Makefiles depend on two supporting Makefiles for common logic. The first is
, provided by the Playdate SDK, which includes rules for compiling/linking C source code and packaging object files into playdate-executable (pdx) files. The second is
, provided by this repository, includes rules and flags for compiling Swift source code.
uses the
executable, the
environment variable, and other tools from the Playdate SDK to select a Swift compiler (
) executable and determine compiler flags needed to target both the Playdate Simulator and device.
See
for details on how to obtain a Swift toolchain’s identifier and build with a specific toolchain.
To build an example with make, enter the example’s directory and run

After the build completes, the example directory will include a pdx file which can be run on the Playdate Simulator and device. To run the game on the simulator, launch the “Playdate Simulator.app” included in the Playdate SDK and open the game using the File > Open menu item.
Alternatively, the game can be run by launching the simulator executable with the pdx file as the first argument on the command line.
Learn more about
Prerequisites: Install Nova, the Playdate extension, and the Icarus extension.
Configure the Icarus Swift language support extension to use a Swift nightly toolchain. See
for instructions on how to install a nightly toolchain.

Navigate to the extension library using the Extension > Extension Library menu bar item or press Cmd+Shift+2. Select the Icarus extension, then select the Settings panel. Finally, select the “Toolchain: Custom” option and provide a full path to your nightly toolchain in the “Custom Toolchain Path” field.
This path should end in
Icarus uses the
built by SwiftPM to drive autocomplete and other editor integration. In order for this to work properly, you must first manually perform a release build in the example directory.
Lastly, we need to create a debug symlink the release build directory.

Why is this needed? By default SourceKit-LSP looks for a debug build, but can be configured to use a release build. Unfortunately, Icarus does not yet allow us to pass custom SourceKit-LSP options, so we trick SourceKit-LSP into working by pretending our release build is a debug build.
The examples included in this repository have been preconfigured with Panic’s Playdate extension for Nova found under each example’s
directory.

Open an example directory with Nova and select the Run icon in the toolbar or press Cmd+R on your keyboard to start a build. After a successful build, Nova will automatically open the Simulator with the newly built game.
Learn more about
Prerequisites: Install VSCode and the Swift extension.
Configure the VSCode Swift extension to use a Swift nightly toolchain. See
for instructions on how to install a nightly toolchain.
Under the Swift Settings, select the “Swift: Path” option and provide a full path to the
folder inside your nightly toolchain.
Under the Swift Settings, select the “Swift > Sourcekit-LSP: Server Arguments” option and pass the arguments
The Swift extension uses the
built by SwiftPM to drive autocomplete and other editor integration. In order for this to work properly, you must first manually perform a release build in the example directory.
The examples included in this repository have been preconfigured with VSCode
files found under each example’s
directory.

Open an example directory with VSCode and select the Terminal > Run Build Task menu item or press Cmd+Shift+B on your keyboard to start a build. After a successful build, VSCode will automatically open the Simulator with the newly built game.
Learn more about
To build an example with swift package manager, enter the example’s directory, set the TOOLCHAINS environment variable to the name of your Swift nightly toolchain, and run
in release mode.
After a successful build, the
directory will contain object files for the host machine. While these objects be cannot by directly packaged into a pdx, it is a good indication that the build will also succeed with
Learn more about
Xcode 15.3+ is required to run the examples in Xcode.
Open an example’s
with Xcode via the command line or the Xcode graphical interface.
Select your Swift nightly toolchain from the Xcode > Toolchains menu item.
Select the Run icon in the toolbar or press Cmd+R on your keyboard to start a build. This will first build the example for the host machine using
. After a successful initial build, Xcode will automatically build again with
then open the Simulator with the newly built game.
Learn more about
When using

to build the examples, the latest installed Swift toolchain is automatically used. However is it sometimes useful to specify a specific toolchain version and is always necessary when building with the Swift Package Manager in terminal.
The Makefile automatic toolchain selection will prefer Swift toolchains installed for the current user take precedence over globally installed toolchains.
In order to select a specific toolchain to build with you will need to frist determine the toolchain’s identifier.
A toolchain’s identifier can be found under the
key in the
file in the toolchain root directory.
If you selected
Install for all users on this computer
when installing your toolchain, you can retrieve the toolchain’s identifier by running the following command in your terminal:
If you instead selected
Install for me only
, you can retrieve the toolchain’s identifier by running the following command in your terminal:
If you have both locally and globally installed toolchains, you can use a single command to determine the identifier of the latest toolchain(s):
Option 1: Set
as an environment variable to your toolchain’s identifier. This only works when building with
or
and will not work when building with a graphical editor.
Option 2: For make based builds only, you can alternatively specify your toolchain name in the
file.

abstract.text: Build the examples with your favorite editor and tools.
Learn about writing games by playing Conway’s Game of Life and Swift Break.
